text: DOJ will not release anything from the Mueller Report today, @PaulaReidCBS reports.
author: stevenportnoy

text: DOJ tells CBS's @ClareHymes22 the "principal conclusions" of the Mueller Report will be made public as they are given to Congress.
author: stevenportnoy

text: Barr says he remains committed "to much transparency as possible."
author: stevenportnoy

text: Attorney General Barr says he'll work this weekend to brief key members of Congress on the "principal conclusions" of Mueller's report... and then consult w/Mueller & Rosenstein to determine how much to publicly release.
author: stevenportnoy

text:
Mueller ends his work 675 days after his appointment.  That's one year, ten months, six days.

But the investigation was begun by the FBI in the summer of 2016.
author: stevenportnoy

text:
THIS WEEKEND ?!

Barr, in letter to Congress, says "I may be in a position to advise you of the Special Counsel's principal conclusions as soon as this weekend."
author: stevenportnoy

text: BREAKING: The Mueller Report has been turned in to the Justice Department, officials say.
author: stevenportnoy

text:
JUST IN: @PressSec tells reporters traveling with Trump that the ISIS caliphate has been 100 percent eliminated in Syria.

Acting SecDef Shanahan was on board AF1 for the trip to Florida to brief Trump.
author: stevenportnoy

text: "I've never heard that," Trump said, when asked about Jared Kushner's reported use of a texting app. "I've never heard about it," he said.
author: stevenportnoy

text:
It has been 675 days since Rod Rosenstein signed the order appointing Robert Mueller… 

One year, ten months, six days…
author: stevenportnoy

text: This, as the world still waits for his administration's plan for Mideast peace...
author: stevenportnoy

text: Congratulations to @MattPieper, the new weekday overnight anchor of our hourly newscasts on @CBSNewsRadio!  http://bit.ly/2JvnaOX
author: stevenportnoy

text: "I didn't get a thank you," Trump said, at the US Army's Joint Systems Manufacturing Center in Lima, Ohio.
author: stevenportnoy

text: Trump, speaking to military crowd at an Ohio tank plant, says he "gave [McCain] the kind of funeral that he wanted," intimating it was a favor for a man he never thought much of.
author: stevenportnoy

text: HAPPENING NOW: Giving a speech at a tank plant in Ohio, Trump accuses John McCain of turning Steele dossier over to FBI because he was "hoping to put me in jeopardy."
author: stevenportnoy

text:
One of my favorite reads in this morning's paper. 

Long before there were overnight presidential tweets about "SNL," there were late night telephone rants about the Smothers Brothers...
author: stevenportnoy

text: Later in the news conference, President Trump later said he was "very proud" to hear the Brazilian leader use the phrase "fake news."
author: stevenportnoy

text:
Brazil's president Jair Bolsonaro just told his American counterpart at the White House:

"Brazil and the United States stand side-by-side ... in respect to traditional family lifestyles ... against the gender ideology ... politically correct attitudes, and against fake news."
author: stevenportnoy

text: "He has my full support," Trump said as reporters departed the Oval Office just now.
author: stevenportnoy

text: NEW: Trump tells pooler that Labor Sec. Alex Acosta still enjoys his full support.
author: stevenportnoy

text: "I think that's disgraceful. Plus there are other things. I was never a fan of John McCain and I never will be," Trump says.
author: stevenportnoy

text: "I'm very unhappy that he didn't repeal and replace Obamacare," Trump says in Oval, when asked why he's attacked John McCain seven months after the senator's death. "Our country would have saved a trillion dollars, and we would have had great health care."
author: stevenportnoy

text: When reports of big payments to Cohen for his "insights" into the Trump White House first surfaced last spring, I asked @PressSec ...
author: stevenportnoy

text: "In total, from on or about January 31, 2017 to on or about February 1, 2018, the Essential Consultants Account received approximately $3,033,112.98 in transfers and checks from the aforementioned entities."
author: stevenportnoy

text: "On or about May 22, 2017, the Essential Consultants Account received a $150,000 deposit from an account at Kazkommertsbank, a Kazakhstani bank."
author: stevenportnoy

text:
"On or about May 10, 2017, June 9, 2017, July 10, 2017 and November 27, 2017, the Essential Consultants Account received four deposits in the amount of $150,000 ... [from] Korea Aerospace Industries."

Total payments -- $600,000.
author: stevenportnoy

text:
"Beginning in or about April 2017, the Essential Consultants Account started receiving wire payments from a bank account associated with ... AT&T Inc."

Total payments -- $600,000.
author: stevenportnoy

text:
"Beginning on or about April 5, 2017, the Essential Consultants Account began receiving payments from ... [what FBI believed to be] the in-house financial subsidiary of the Swiss pharmaceutical company Novartis International AG."

Total payments -- $1,099,780.
author: stevenportnoy

text:
More from court docs: "Beginning on or about January 31, 2017, Cohen began receiving monthly payments of $83,333 into the Essential Consultants Account from an entity... controlled by Russian national Viktor Vekselberg."

Seven payments totaled $583,333.
author: stevenportnoy

text: From newly-unsealed court documents: When he opened a checking account for Essential Consultants LLC, Michael Cohen told a bank employee that it would serve as "a real estate consulting company to collect fees for investment consulting work."
author: stevenportnoy

text:
This president and his Brazilian counterpart will submit themselves to questions from a free global press later today. 

We'll have anchored live coverage on your @CBSNewsRadio station at approximately 1:45pET.
author: stevenportnoy

text: So proud to celebrate @DavidBegnaud, who has swiftly earned his place in the proud history of @CBSNews. Keep following your heart, David. @RTDNA #FirstAmendment
author: stevenportnoy

text: .@AmericanAir says the government's move to ground the 737 Max 8 is "based on new information," and "out of an abundance of caution." Two dozen AA aircraft are affected, the airline says.
author: stevenportnoy

text: Thanks!
author: stevenportnoy

text: Thanks to @ClareHymes22 @ArdenFarhi and @ZoeTellsItAll for their assistance in getting the details and color of the Manafort sentencing to our @CBSNews audiences on radio, digital and TV.
author: stevenportnoy

text: Thanks for following along! Glad to be your eyes and ears.
author: stevenportnoy

text: Thanks for following along! Glad to be your eyes and ears.
author: stevenportnoy

text: The consensus estimate among reporters at the courthouse is that Manafort has been sentenced to 90 months in prison, minus nine months credit for time served.
author: stevenportnoy

text:
A bunch of journalists, only some of whom have actual legal experience, are trying to figure this out ... 

It is not clear as I tweet this how much prison time Manafort has been sentenced to.

But it's several years. Certainly more than 47 months.
author: stevenportnoy

text: BREAKING: Judge Jackson sentences Paul Manafort to 73 months in prison, some of which will run *concurrent* to the sentence handed down last week.
author: stevenportnoy

text: We're doing the math right now ... It's quite confusing at this point, but Jackson says Manafort will be sentenced to MORE time than the judge in Virginia handed down last week.
author: stevenportnoy

text: Jackson says she will issue a "separate consecutive sentence" on top of what Ellis handed down last week.
author: stevenportnoy

text: More to come, but Judge Jackson says because some of Manafort's conduct has already been addressed by another court, 30 months of the sentence she'll issue here will overlap with the sentence Judge Ellis issued last wk in Virginia.
author: stevenportnoy

text: Here we go.  Getting into the sentencing math ...
author: stevenportnoy

text: Judge Jackson says she agrees with Manafort (as did Judge Ellis last week) that the 19-24 year guideline "overstates the seriousness of this offense."
author: stevenportnoy

text: "The defendant was not in the SHU!" Jackson says, blasting the Manafort defense team for making it seem as though their client was in solitary confinement.
author: stevenportnoy

text: Jackson says the "No Collusion refrain" of the Manafort defense provides her with "just one more thing that's inconsistent with any genuine acceptance of responsibility."
author: stevenportnoy

text: "The 'No Collusion' mantra is simply a non-sequitur," Jackson says.
author: stevenportnoy

text: Jackson is now mocking the defense for repeatedly referencing what she calls the "No Collusion refrain" in their filings. The question of Russian collusion is "unrelated to the maters at hand," Jackson says.
author: stevenportnoy

text:
Judge Jackson says Manafort's pre-sentence filings stressed the impact of the prosecution on him and his family. As in, "'Look what they've done to ME.'" 

Anything suggesting remorse prior to his sentencing was "completely absent" from the submissions, Jackson says.
author: stevenportnoy

text: Jackson: "There's no question that this defendant knew better, and he knew exactly what he was doing."
author: stevenportnoy

text: "He did plead guilty. He did sit for many sessions," Jackson says. "But the problem is, the defendant's own conduct makes it impossible to assess" how truthful his testimony was.
author: stevenportnoy

text: Jackson says Manafort's lies can't be ignored, as "court is one of those places where facts still matter."
author: stevenportnoy

text: Jackson says Manafort had "contempt for" and "believed he had the right to manipulate these proceedings."
author: stevenportnoy

text: Jackson says Manafort's "dissembling in this case began with the bond proceedings and it never abated."
author: stevenportnoy

text:
Jackson says Manafort acted through the proceeding, after his guilty plea, with an "'I'm just gonna manage this, I'm just gonna spin this' attitude."

She says he still isn't being straight with her.
author: stevenportnoy

text: Judge Jackson says Manafort was "hiding the truth of who he represented from policymakers and the public," behaving in a way that "undermines our political discourse and infects our policymaking."
author: stevenportnoy

text:
Jackson slams Manafort - 

"It is hard to overstate the number of lies and the amount of fraud and the extraordinary amount of money involved" in Manafort's crimes.

She says there is "no explanation" from Manafort that would warrant the leniency he has requested.
author: stevenportnoy

text: Jackson says Russian collusion was "not presented" in this case, and therefore not resolved by it, one way or the other.
author: stevenportnoy

text: Jackson says Manafort was neither "public enemy number one" nor a "victim," adding that the case has been marked by a fair amount of "hyperbole" on both sides.
author: stevenportnoy

text:
WE'RE BACK.

Judge Amy Berman Jackson is taking the bench.
author: stevenportnoy

text: Judge Jackson calls a recess of about :20-:25 minutes.
author: stevenportnoy

text:
Manafort says the case has taken everything from him -- his cash, his properties, his trust accounts for his children.

Manafort asks that the judge not take him from his wife.

"I ask that you find compassion in your sentencing."
author: stevenportnoy

text:
Manafort says he takes responsibility for his actions.

"I pledge do to all I can to accelerate the healing process."
author: stevenportnoy

text: Manafort says the support of friends and family have "had an energizing impact on my life," adding that he is a "different person from the one who came before you" in the fall of 2017.
author: stevenportnoy

text:
"I concede I did not always behave in ways that supported my core values."

"I say to you in the future that my behavior will be very different. I have already begun to change."
author: stevenportnoy

text:
"I want to apologize ..."

"While I cannot undo the past, I can assure that the future will be very different."
author: stevenportnoy

text:
From his wheelchair, Manafort reiterates his shame, which he mentioned in court last week, but adds an explicit apology.

"I want to say to you now that I am sorry for what I have done."
author: stevenportnoy

text: MANAFORT IS SPEAKING NOW.
author: stevenportnoy

text:
Downing suggested there's a "political motivation" for what he sees as an "out of whack" level of attention on the case. 

Judge Jackson then prompted Downing to say on the record that he doesn't believe the prosecutors are motivated by politics.
author: stevenportnoy

text: Downing says the media attention on Manafort has created a "very harsh process" for his client, different from how he presumes another defendant facing the same charges might be viewed by the public and the press. "Everybody's going nuts over this," he laments.
author: stevenportnoy

text: This is apparently the first time this has been mentioned in open court ... It's apparently been part of redactions in court filings ...
author: stevenportnoy

text:
Defense atty Downing, arguing for his client, is referencing sealed portions of the case.  

Offering what he hopes will be a mitigating factor, Downing says Manafort and Kilimnik were in communication about their activities in Ukraine with the US Embassy in Kiev.
author: stevenportnoy

text: Defense attorney Kevin Downing is now making his argument. "[Manafort] truly is sorry for violating the law."
author: stevenportnoy

text: Wrapping up his argument for a tough sentence, Weissmann says Manafort has "sought to undermine, not promote, American ideals."
author: stevenportnoy

text: Weissmann says Manafort's decision to tamper with witnesses while he's under indictment and out on bail suggests "something that is wrong" with his moral compass.
author: stevenportnoy

text: Weissmann says Manafort's crimes, including witness tampering, "go to the heart of the American criminal justice system."
author: stevenportnoy

text:
Weissmann says Manafort's belated 2017 FARA filing was "woefully false and incomplete," leaving out his work for Ukraine and Yanukovych.

"It neither would, could or should be absolution for a criminal prosecution."
author: stevenportnoy

text:
Weissmann notes Manafort had to decline a job in the Reagan administration because he was audited by the Justice Department for his work for overseas clients. 

"It is hard to imagine a more righteous prosecution of this act."
author: stevenportnoy

text: Explaining the crimes Manafort has committed (and to which he has admitted his guilt), prosecutor Weissmann notes Manafort's familiarity with his obligation to register as a foreign agent. "That law got in the way of Mr. Manafort.  Secrecy was integral..."
author: stevenportnoy
